unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities: Load Shedding Grips Several States Across India**
normalised: **Energy and Utilities: Load Shedding Grips Several States Across India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, August 16th - Unscheduled power cuts, commonly known as load shedding, are impacting several states across India, including Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Rajasthan. The surge in demand, coupled with disruptions in coal supply chains and delays in renewable energy projects, is exacerbating the situation.
normalised: New Delhi, August sixteenth - Unscheduled power cuts, commonly known as load shedding, are impacting several states across India, including Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Rajasthan. The surge in demand, coupled with disruptions in coal supply chains and delays in renewable energy projects, is exacerbating the situation.

unnormalised: According to the Ministry of Power, the peak demand has surpassed 220 GW, putting immense pressure on the national grid. Dr. Sharma, Director of the Central Electricity Authority (CEA), stated that efforts are underway to address the coal shortage by expediting transportation and increasing domestic production.
normalised: According to the Ministry of Power, the peak demand has surpassed two hundred and twenty gigawatts, putting immense pressure on the national grid. Doctor Sharma, Director of the Central Electricity Authority (C E A), stated that efforts are underway to address the coal shortage by expediting transportation and increasing domestic production.

unnormalised: In Lucknow, residents reported power outages lasting up to 6 hours daily. Businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises in areas like Hazratganj, are facing significant losses. Mr. Verma, a local businessman, lamented the impact on his printing press, saying his production has dropped by nearly 40%. He estimates losses to be around Rs. 50,000 per week. The erratic power supply also affects essential services like hospitals and water pumping stations, impacting thousands. Many households are relying on costly diesel generators, impacting the air quality, in addition to their pockets. There are concerns that it may take up to 2 weeks to stabilize the situation as the government ramps up coal imports. Some areas, especially those with newly constructed apartments in the suburbs lacking adequate backup power, are experiencing difficulties with amenities like lifts, affecting residents living on upper floors. One resident of a 1200 sq ft flat in Gomti Nagar complained about not having access to water due to the pump not working during a recent 4-hour outage.
